questions.text: Identify the muscle marked as A in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The muscle labeled as A is anconeus and its functions are

  • Abduction of the wrist in pronated position
  • Accessory extension of elbow joint

Other options: 

  • The muscle marked as B is extensor carpi radialis brevis, and it extends and abducts the wrist joint
  • The muscle marked as C is extensor digitorum, and it mainly extends the index, middle, ring, and little fingers and also extends the wrist.
  • The muscle marked as D is extensor carpi ulnaris, and it extends and adducts the wrist joint.

questions.text: The ferrous form is converted to ferric form in the basolateral aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hephaestin (Hp) converts Fe2+(ferrous) to Fe3+ (ferric), which is transported in plasma bound to transferrin.

Other Options:

  • Ferric Reductase (DCYTB): Converts dietary Fe3+ to absorbable Fe2+ in the apical/luminal aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1): Transports Fe2+ from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Ferroportin 1 (FPN1): Transports Fe2+ from the mucosal cell into the interstitial fluid and then into the plasma.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-epileptic drug  is responsible for blisters, erythema, and discoloration of  hand as shown below.?
questions.solution:
Phenytoin is responsible for Purple glove syndrome as shown in the image. 

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly) (First image shown below)

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

Other options: 

Phenobarbitone can also cause blisters (second image shown below) and bullae. But that is usually associated with chronic poisoning and is not an acute reaction. Levitracetam and Lamotrigene and very safe drugs with good efficacy. 

Better alternative for IV phenytoin:

Instead of Phenytoin, IV Fosphenytoin is preferred in the management of status epilepticus. It is a pro-drug and is rapidly converted to Phenytoin and since it is an ester, it seldom causes such reaction. 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes. The flowchart shown below summarizes the management of status epilepticus. 

There are many drugs resulting in acute named syndromes. These are commonly read under the title 'Drug induced Syndromes'. The table below summarizes few of them.

DRUGS SYNDROMES FEATURES TREATMENT
Anticonvulsants, Sulfonamides, Dapsone,
Allopurinol, Minocycline, Gold, Hydroxychloroquine
(HCQ) Sulfate, Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Ethambutol and
Pyrazinamide		 DRESS - Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms syndrome
  • Type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type II T- Helper cells play a role
  • Fever with diffuse maculo-papular rash. 
  • Systemic involvement (Liver and Kindneys > Lungs and Heart)
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Steroids can be used in acute conditions
  • Chronic/ long-standing DRESS needs treatment with Interferon α
L-tryptophan, Amphetamine, Lithium,
Dextromethorphan, Merperidine, Fluoxetine, Trazodone,
Venlafaxine, Buspirone		 Seratonin syndrome
  • Increased serotonergic activity in central neurologic system, due to serotonergic agents. 
  • Neuromuscular (clonus, myoclonus, tremor,
    hyperreflexia)
  • Autonomic (fever, mydriasis, tachycardia,
    tachypnea)
  • Mental status changes (confusion,agitation)
  • Rarely death
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Hyperthermia should be treated with aggressive external cooling measures such as ice, mist, fans and a cooling blanket.
  • Symptomatic support.
  • Cyproheptadine (5-hydroxytryptamine antagonist) is beneficial.
  • Rigidity needs to be treated with Benzodiazepenes. 
Vancomycin, Ciprofloxacin, Amphotericin B, Rifampicin and Teicoplanin Redman syndrome
  • Mild cases sensation of burning and itching, agitation,
    dizziness, headache, chills, fever and perioral paresthesia.
  • pruritus; erythema of the face, neck, and upper torso;
  • severe cases, angioedema
  • cardiovascular collapse
  • antihistamines - Diphenhydramine hydrochloride intravenously averts reaction. 
  • Pretreatment with hydroxyzine can reduce symptoms. 
Amiodarone Blue-gray syndrome
  • Blue-gray skin pigmentation, dyspnea, cough and fever
  • Withdraw the drug.
Dapsone Severe Dapsone Hypersensitivity syndrome
  • High fever lasting for about 4-5 days.
  • malaise, sore throat, dysphagia, productive cough, and pruritic rash
  • methamoglobinemia
  • Corticosteroids orally or topically in mild cases with anti-histamines. 
Butyrophenones, Phenothiazines,
Thioxanthenes, Hydroxyzine, Reserpine;, Amitriptyline,
Amoxapine, Desipramine, Maprotiline, Phenelzine,
Tranylcypromine, Diazepam, Lorazepam, Carbamazepine,
Phenytoin, Amantadine, Bromocriptine, Levodopa, Lithium		 Neurleptic Malignant syndrome
  • Dopaminergic blockade
  • cardinal features
    including autonomic dysfunction
  • altered mental status
  • muscular rigidity, hyperthermia, cogwheel rigidity, dyskinesia, dysphagia, festinating gait, lead pipe muscle rigidity
  • oculogyric crisis 
  • opisthotonos
  • Withdraw the drug
  • Treat hyperthermia by cooling measures.
  • Bromocriptine and Dantrolene sodium.
Penicillin Nicolau Syndrome (Livedoid Dermatitis)
  • Pain around the injection site soon after injection, followed by erythema, livedoid patch, haemorrhagic patch, finally resulting into the necrosis of skin, subcutaneous fat, and muscle. 
  • Stop the drug.
  • Wound care includes antibiotics, dressings and flap reconstructions.
  • Use of Vasoactive agents
    (Pentoxyphylline) together with hyperbaric oxygen may be beneficial considering the vascular pathogenesis.
Warfarin Warfarin induced skin necrosis
  • local paresthesias with an erythematous flush followed by intense pain and rapid development of petechiae. 
  • Vitamin K
  • Fresh Frozen Plasma 
  • Wound care.
Abacavir, All-Trans Retinoic Acid,
Bortezomib, Carbamazapine, Celecoxib, Clozapine,
Diclofenac, Diazepam, Furosemide, Hydralazine, Imatinib,
Lenalidomide, Minocycline, Nitrofurantoin, Norfloxacin,
Ofloxacin, Pegfilgastrin, Propylthiouracil, Quinupristin, Dalfopristin, Trimethoprim-Sulfamethoxazole		 Sweet syndrome
  • relapsing polychondritis, drug-induced lupus, and development of Anti-Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies (ANCA).
  • fever, leukocytosis, painful
    erythematous and edematous papules, plaques and nodules
    are seen to be infiltrated by neutrophils. 
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Corticosteroids orally or topically in mild cases with anti-histamines.
Ibuprofen, Allopurinol, Chloroquine,
Penicillamine, Sulfasalazine, Carbamazepine, Etosuximide,
Phenobarbital, Phenytoin, Valpoic Acid, Amoxicillin,
Imipenem, Ciprofloxacin, Clindamycin, Doxycyclin,
Erythromycin, Sulfadiazine, Sulfamethoxazole, Trimethoprim, Dapsone, Fluconazole, Nystatin, Nevirapine,
Abacavir, Efavirenz, Tamoxifen, Verapamil, Enalapril, Acetazolamide.		 Steven - Johnson syndrome
  • Erythema with bullous, eroded lesions of skin
  • cholestatic liver disease. 
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Electrolyte and fluid imbalance to be corrected.
  • Corticosteroids orally
Sulfonamides, Pyrazolones, Barbiturates,
Ibuprofen, Allopurinol and Carbamazepine.		 Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Lyell Syndrome)
  • It comes under spectrum of autoimmune blistering disease, including linear IgA
    dermatosis and paraneoplastic pemphigus.
  • nail dystrophies, ocular complications, trichiasis, symblepharon, distichiasis, visual loss, entropion, ankyloblepharon, lagophthalmos and corneal ulceration.
  • Hyper/ Hypo pigmentation of skin. 
  • withdrawal of the
    causative drug
  • systemic steroids
  • Cyclophosphamide seems helpful.
All anti-psychotics carry the risk  Rabbit syndrome
  • characterized by involuntary, rhythmic, fast and fine
    movements of the oral and masticatory muscles along the vertical axis of the mouth.
  • Accompanied by popping sound
  • Does not involve the tongue.
  • Anticholinergic agents such as Benztropine, Biperiden, Procyclidine and Trihexyphenidyl
Anticonvulsants, Sulfonamides, Penicillins,
Allopurinol, Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs		 Vanishing Bile Duct Syndrome (VBDS)
  • progressive cholestasis
  • Drugs act as a hapten and produce autoantibodies
    against cytokeratin which is in the bile duct, skin,
    conjunctival epithelium and orogenital mucosa.
  • pruritis, weight loss, malaise,
    disappearance of intrahepatic bile duct
  • Withdraw the drug
  • Symptomatic management
  • Use of choleretics
  • Corticosteroids

Chemotherapeutic drugs:

5-Fluorouracil, Doxorubicin, Docetaxel,
Idarubicin, and Cytarabine

 Hand-Foot syndrome
  • Palmar-Plantar
    Erythrodysaesthesia
  • Erythema, tenderness, tingling, numbness, dry
    rash and desquamation over the palms and soles.
  • discontinuation of the causative drug and
    symptomatic care.
  • Steroids and pyridoxine 

Phenytoin

 Purple glove syndrome
  • Intravenous administration of phenytoin resulting
    in soft tissue injury at the site of injection leading to oedema and purplish-black discoloration of the hand.
  • limb elevation
  • physiotherapy
  • low concentration local anaesthetic for brachial plexus block. 

Lithium and Levodopa

 Creutzfeldt-Jakob like Syndrome (CJS)
  • Dementia, confusional state, myoclonus, Parkinson's syndrome, dystonia, grimacing, dysarthria,
    oculogyric crisis, blepharospasm, swallowing difficulties, torticollis and trismus.
  • Withdraw the drug.

Biologics like TNF-Α antagonist, adalimumab, infliximab,
etanercept, α-Interferon and other cytokines. 

 Psuedolymphoma syndrome
  • Fever, cutaneous eruption, lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly
  • Withdraw the drug.
  • Folic acid is promising. 

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism in Q fever?

choices.text: There is no vector involved in the transmission of this disease
It is a category A bioterrorism agent
Doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine are preferred for treatment
Indirect immunofluorescence is the best investigation for diagnosis

questions.solution:
Q fever is caused by Coxiella burnetti which is a Bioterrorism category B agent and should be cultivated in only biosafety level 3 laboratories.

It is a zoonotic disease and the most commonly identified sources of human infection are farm animals, such as cattle, goats, and sheep. Infected mammals shed C. burnetii in their urine, feces, milk, and placenta. Human exposure to C. burnetii may occur as a result of inhalation of contaminated aerosols arising from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions and consumption of unpasteurized contaminated milk. There is no vector involved in the transmission of the disease to man. Ticks can act as reservoirs.

Incubation period usually lasts for 2 to 3 weeks.

People working with farm animals and veterinarians are at a higher risk of infection.

Infection can be acute or chronic. Acute disease resembles influenza (fever, chills, headache), nonbacterial (atypical) pneumonia, and hepatitis. There is no skin lesion.

Chronic Q fever lasts more than 6 months. Infective endocarditis is the most common form of disease in this phase. Blood cultures for bacteria are negative, and there is a high titer of antibodies to C burnetii.

Diagnosis:

Serology is the diagnostic method of choice for Coxiella brunettii which shows a rise in the titer of specific antibodies to C. burnetii. But indirect immunofluorescence is considered the best method. PCR is useful in diagnosing culture-negative endocarditis.

A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Treatment:

Doxycycline is the drug of choice for the treatment of acute Q fever. Chronic Q fever requires treatment for at least 18 months with doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine.

Prevention:

Currently, “high-temperature, short-time” pasteurization at 71.5°C for 15 seconds is recommended to destroy viable Coxiella species in milk.

Pasteurization can be done by heating the Milk  at either 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in the Holder method.

Relative bradycardia/Faget’s sign is seen when patients have a lower heart rate than might be expected for a given body temperature.

The body temperature is often considered an independent determinant of heart rate.

It is estimated that for every centigrade rise in temperature, the heart rate increases approximately by 10 bpm.

Infectious causes of relative bradycardia include: 

  • Salmonella typhi
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Brucella spp.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
  • Leptospira interrogans
  • Legionella pneumophila
  • Rickettsia spp.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Plasmodium spp. (malaria)

Viruses/viral infections:

  • Yellow fever virus
  • Dengue virus
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers - Early in course of Marburg and Ebola
  • Viral myocarditis

questions.text: Which of the following is false about RB as the governor of cell cycle?

choices.text: The function of RB protein is to regulate at the G1-S checkpoint
Hypophosphorylated state of the RB promote cell cycle progression
Active RB binds and inhibits the E2F family of transcription factors preventing transcription of cyclin E

questions.solution:
Hyperphosphorylated state (inactive) of RB protein promotes cell cycle progression.

RB, called the Governor of Proliferation is a key negative regulator of the G1/S cell cycle transition and is directly or indirectly inactivated in most human cancers.

  • The normal RB gene is present on chromosome 13q14.
  • RB -  active hypophosphorylated state in quiescent cells and an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells passing through the G1/S cell cycle transition.
  • Cyclin D/CDK-4 phosphorylates RB inactivating the protein, and releases E2F to induce target genes such as cyclin E.
  • RB -  antiproliferative effects by binding and inhibiting E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing transcription of cyclin E, required for cells to pass through the G1-S phase cell cycle checkpoint.
  • The antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:
    • Loss-of-function mutations affecting RB
    • Gene amplification of CDK4 and cyclin D genes
    • Loss of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/INK4a)
    • Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB (E7 protein of HPV)

Loss-of-function mutations of the RB gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, a subset of glioblastomas, small-cell carcinomas of the lung, breast cancers, and bladder carcinomas.

questions.text: You are a medical officer actively spearheading the STD control program in your block. As part of this, the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are investigated and treated for the disease. This type of case detection that is employed by your team is  called ___________
questions.solution:
Method of case detection in control of STDs when the sexual partners of the diagnosed patients are tested and treated is contact tracing.

Methods employed in case of detection of STDs are

  • Screening: testing of apparently healthy volunteers from the general population for early detection of disease.
  • Contact tracing: the technique by which the sexual partners of diagnosed patients are identified, located, investigated, and treated.
  • Cluster testing: the patients are asked to name other persons of either sex who move in the same socio-sexual environment.

questions.text: A patient presents with a past history headache, fatigue and cyclical fever for which was treated with medication. Now he presents with complaints of glare and discomfort of the eyes. Findings seen on slit lamp examination are given below. Which of the following findings would you expect to see on a fundoscopy?
questions.solution:
The fundoscopy will reveal a Bull’s eye maculopathy

The given clinical scenario and the given slit lamp findings of Cornea verticillata point to a treatment of suspected malarial fever with Chloroquine.

Chloroquine is often implicated in the findings of Bull’s eye maculopathy.  

The image below shows Bull’s eye maculopathy.

Other causes of Bull’s eye maculopathy are: 

  • Chloroquine maculopathy
  • Advanced Stargardt disease
  • Cone and cone-rod dystrophy
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy Clofazimine retinopathy.

Cornea Verticillata is a reversible, asymptomatic condition where a whorl-like opacity is seen in the corneal epithelium seen on treatment with medica­tion such as chloroquine, amiodarone, phenothiazines and indomethacin.

It is also seen in Fabry disease and its carrier state.

Hypotonic maculopathy is common in eyes developing hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.

questions.text: The center for the reflex that protects the cochlea from exposure to loud sounds is :
questions.solution:
The center for the stapedial reflex that protects the cochlea from exposure to loud sounds is Superior Olivary Complex.

Related Pearl: Stapedial reflex

Principle: A loud sound 70- 100dB above the threshold of hearing of patient, leads to bilateral contraction of the stapedius muscle.

Afferent: 8th cranial nerve.

Efferent: 7th cranial nerve.

Centre: Superior olivary complex in the brainstem.

In afferent palsy, the reflex is absent on both sides and in efferent palsy reflex is absent only on the side of the lesion.

Clinical significance:

  • Can identify malingerers.
  • To differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss: The threshold is decreased in cochlear lesions because of recruitment whereas it is increased or even absent in retrocochlear lesions.
  • Acoustic reflex decay: It is a feature of retrocochlear hearing loss (8th nerve lesion). A sustained tone of 500-1000Hz delivered 10dB above acoustic reflex threshold, for a period of 10 seconds, brings the amplitude to 50% (abnormal decay).
  • Identify the site of facial nerve: Its presence indicates that the lesion is beyond the nerve to stapedius.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the hospital with the following lesions on the body. The lesion started 2 days ago and has increased in number. Similar lesions are also present on the lower limbs. Examination of the oral cavity also has similar lesions. Which of the following infection most commonly proceeds with this skin condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows target lesions that are seen in erythema multiforme. Infection with Herpes simplex commonly proceeds with this skin condition.

Erythema Multiforme is a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

The common triggers are

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy: carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drug reactions: sulfonamides, cotrimoxazole, penicillins
  • Miscellaneous: Lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), Sarcoidosis, Polyarteritis Nodosa

It presents clinically with macular, popular, or urticarial lesions, along with the classic acral iris or target lesions. The lesions are distributed on the distal extremities, palms or trunk, and oral and genital mucous membranes.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  • The central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  • Middle paler zone of edema
  • The outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge

Atypical lesions will have only 2 zones. They fade in 1-2 weeks leaving dusky discoloration.

 

Related Pearl: Erythema multiforme vs. Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis

Earlier, erythema multiforme (EM), Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN or Lyell syndrome) were considered to form a spectrum from mild to fulminatingly severe cases. Now, this has been revised to separate Erythema multiforme as part of a different spectrum.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.


Stevens–Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, in which SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

  Erythema multiforme major Stevens-Johnsons Syndrome Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis
% Body Surface-area <10% <10% >30%
Causes Herpes simplex> Mycoplasma infection Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol Drug induced e.g. cephalosporins, sulfa drugs, allopurinol
Associated Symptoms Less fever and other constitutional symptoms Fever, malaise and headache Fever, malaise and headache
Mucosal Lesions Milder mucosal lesions Severe mucosal involvement Severe mucosal involvement
Lesions Erythematous papules, Target lesions, raised atypical target lesions, occasional bullous lesions

Vesicles on erythematous base, erosions, purpuric macules, Flat atypical target lesions

Nikolsky Sign Positive

Diffuse, generalized epidermal detachment

TEN with spots - with widespread purpuric macules and flat atypical target lesions

TEN without spots- loss of large epidermal sheets without purpuric macules or target lesions

 Nikolsky Sign Positive
Distribution Acral – distal extremities Variable distribution Extensive distribution
Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality

 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Haematoma

A localized tumour‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in colour from the surrounding skin. It can be of any colour or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is < 1cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate haemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion > 1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of oedema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumour

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <0.5cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >0.5 cm in diameter 
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5cm. Some authors define nodules as >1cm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of excess uncontrollable worry over daily life activities, finance, and his health over the past 2 years. Because of this, he feels restless most of the time. He also complains of fatigue and disturbed sleep. Which of the following drugs are the first-line choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms favour a diagnosis of generalised anxiety disorder. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are the first-line choice in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder.

Generalised anxiety disorder is characterized by:

  • Excessive anxiety and worry about a number of events or activities for at least 6 months.
  • Associated with three (or more) of the following.
    • Restlessness
    • Being easily fatigued
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Irritability
    • Muscle tension
    • Sleep disturbance

Short acting benzodiazepines such as alprazolam are used during acute episodes.

CBT is advised along with SSRIs.

Related Pearl: Generalised anxiety disorder

Generalised anxiety disorder

DSM-5 Criteria:

  • Excessive worry, anxiety(multiple issues) ≥ 6 months
  • Difficult to control

3 or more of following symptoms:

  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Not due to substances, another mental disorder

Treatment:

First line:

  • Cognitive behavioural therapy
  • SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line:

  • Benzodiazepines
  • Buspirone

questions.text: Right sided fish hook ureter is seen in ______
questions.solution:
Right sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters ("J-shaped ureters" or "hockey stick ureter") describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.
  • Circumcaval ureter, or retrocaval ureter, is a developmental anomaly of the inferior vena cava (IVC). This congenital abnormality occurs as a result of the right supracardinal system failing to develop normally. The right posterior cardinal vein persists, and therefore ends up passing in front of the ureter. The anomaly always occurs on the right side, as this is the side of the normal IVC.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker patient is brought to the hospital due to pain and weakness in the left arm for the past week. He also complains of left-sided chest pain for the last 3 weeks along with malaise, fever and weight loss for the past month. Which of the following tests is more likely to point to the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features of left-sided chest pain, fever, weight loss, and malaise combined with pain and weakness of the left arm are suggestive of a Pancoast tumor. Chest CT is the best test to arrive at the diagnosis in this patient.

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or postobstructive pneumonitis.

A regional spread can cause:

  • Tracheal obstruction,
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Physical examination demonstrates crepitus over the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound evaluation reveals air in the walls of the gall bladder. What is the indicated management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and USG findings of air in the wall of the gall bladder are suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis. This is managed with emergency cholecystectomy.

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a life-threatening form of acute cholecystitis that is more common in older patients with diabetes mellitus. The term refers to the presence of gas in the gallbladder lumen or wall. It is due to a secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii. Escherichia coli, staphylococci, streptococci, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella may also be isolated.

Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination. Mild to moderate unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may be present. USG reveals air in the walls of the gall bladder.

Emphysematous cholecystitis often heralds the development of gangrene, perforation, and other complications. Hence emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the management of these patients.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy had fallen on outstretched hands and presented with pain and swelling over his left elbow. His X-ray image is shown below. Which among the following classification is used in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray image is suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus (extension type) and Gartland classification is used in this case.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

  • Most commonly seen in children of 5-8 years.
  • Most common type of supracondylar fracture : Extension type> Flexion type.
  • Most common mechanism of injury: Fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension.
  • Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures.

Gartland classification (in children):

  • Type I: Undisplaced
  • Type II: Displaced but posterior cortex is intact
  • Type III: Displaced but no intact posterior cortex and distal fragment could be either displaced:
    • Posteromedial
    • Posterolateral
  • Type IV: Complete loss of anterior and posterior periosteal hinge making it unstable in both flexion and extension

Three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Three-point bony landmarks in elbow are the tips of medial and lateral epicondyles and the olecranon.

Characteristic displacements in Supracondylar fracture(Mnemonic: MID)

  • M- Medial rotation/medial tilt.
  • I- Impaction (proximal shift).
  • D- Dorsal displacement/dorsal tilt.

Nerve injury

  • Most common nerve to be injured in extension type: Anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU)
  • Most common nerve to be injured in flexion type : Ulnar nerve.

Vessel injury

  • Most common vessel to be injured: Brachial artery.

On examination:

  • Unusual posterior prominence of tip of olecranon.
  • Three point bony relationship is maintained with respect to each other but not with respect to the shaft of humerus.

Complications:

  • Malunion (Most common): Posteromedially displaced fracture  tend to develop Cubitus Varus (Gun stock deformity)
  • Nerve injury: usually neuropraxia, hence transient.
  • Volkmann’s ischemic contracture and compartment syndrome (Most common fracture to cause this in children)
  • Non union is unknown.

Treatment of Supracondylar fracture:

  • Closed reduction and K-wire fixation.
  • Tractions used: Dunlop and Smith's.

Treatment of Cubitus Varus deformity

  • Lateral closed wedge osteotomy - French
  • Medial open wedge osteotomy - King's

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include
questions.solution:
Partial mole does not come under gestational trophoblastic neoplasm.

The malignant forms of gestational trophoblastic disease are termed gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). These include

  • Invasive mole
  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Placental site trophoblastic tumor
  • Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor
